title: OFLAT (OCamlFlat)
description: OCaml library + browser web app compiled with js_of_ocaml and deployed as a static site via GitLab Pages.
subtitle: Static Web App + OCaml Library (js_of_ocaml)
overview: OFLAT is a two-part OCaml project: an OCaml library (OCamlFlat) and a web app compiled to JavaScript with js_of_ocaml. The CI pipeline builds the static assets and publishes them to GitLab Pages, including a version.txt breadcrumb to identify the deployed commit.

coreConcept.summary: Combine a reusable OCaml library with a browser app compiled from OCaml.
bullets: Two-project workflow: OCamlFlat library + OFLAT web app
Web app compiled from OCaml via js_of_ocaml
Static output (HTML/CSS/JS) ready for GitLab Pages or any static host
CI deploy includes a version.txt breadcrumb for traceability

features: Local, reproducible dependencies via a recommended local opam switch (./_opam/)
Independent builds: OCamlFlat (make) and OFLAT (make run)
GitLab Pages deployment from the built public/ output
Cache-busting in CI by rewriting asset URLs with ?v=$CI_COMMIT_SHA
Extra functionality added around Turing Machine support in both OCaml-Flat and OFLAT

frontendStack: OCaml compiled to JavaScript via js_of_ocaml
projectStructure: my-oflat/: OFLAT web app compiled to JS via js_of_ocaml (built via make)
CI copies the built web app into public/ for Pages deployment
version.txt emitted in the Pages artifact to identify the deployed commit
deployment: GitLab CI builds the static assets and publishes them via GitLab Pages
Pages job rewrites asset URLs in public/index.html with cache-busting query params
Live URL available in GitLab under Deploy → Pages

personalExperience:
OFLAT is a personal variant inspired by a thesis project series funded by FACTOR to promote OCaml. I couldn't recover the original source code, so I rebuilt the project from available material and extended it—especially around Turing Machine functionality—across both OCaml-Flat and the OFLAT web app.

This was a great exercise in building a clean two-project workflow (library + web app), keeping dependencies reproducible with opam, and making the deployment fully static and automated through GitLab Pages.
